newsitem.title: INDIA: India's Hindalco plans aluminium complex.
newsitem.headline: India's Hindalco plans aluminium complex.

text.p: India's largest private aluminium maker Hindalco Industries plans to set up an integrated aluminium complex in the eastern state of Orissa, state officials said on Tuesday.
They said the proposed complex is expected to cost 100 billion rupees.
Orissa government officials said the proposed complex will comprise of a one-million-tonne per annum alumina refinery and a 250,000-tonne per yer greenfield aluminium smelter.
Oficials said Hindalco will take on lease the Kodngamali-Pottangi mines of the state-run Orissa Mining Corp (OMC) to procure bauxite for its refinery.
The smelter will come up near IB valley in western Orissa, officials said. The company also plans to set up a capitve power plant of 600 megawatt close to a coal deposit in the valley.
Officials said Hindalco, a flagship company of the Aditya Birla group, and OMC signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) on Saturday to set up the complex.
"This project is another step to add value to the minerals yet to be exploited in the state," said S.B. Mishra, a senior Orissa government official.
Orissa Chief Minister J.B. Patnaik told Reuters "The details of the terms and conditions, the mining area and other related things will be worked out at the time of signing the agreement.
Hindalco's plant at Renukoot in the northern state of Uttar Pradesh has a aluminium metal production capacity of 210,000 tonnes and alumina output capacity of 350,000 tonnes.
Officials said the company planned to increase its aluminium capcity to 242,000 tonnes and alumina capacity to 450,000 tonnes.
Hindalco is the third Indian company planning an integrated aluminium complex after Indian Aluminium Company (INDAL) and Larsen and Toubro.
